facts.text: This is Writ Petition No. 164 of 1974 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 164 of 1974. Petition Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petition directed against validity of order of detention dated 26th July 1972 made by District Magistrate Midnapur under section 3 of MISA 1971

anchor.surface_text: This petition is directed against the validity of an order of detention dated 26th July, 1972 made by the District Magistrate, Midnapur under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

facts.text: District Magistrate made report to State Government on 26th July 1972

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention was made by the District Magistrate on 26th July, 1972and on the same day he made a report to the State Government.

facts.text: State Government approved the order of detention on 5th August 1972

anchor.surface_text: The State Government approved the order of detention on 5th August, 1972 and a report was made by it to the Central Government on the same day.

facts.text: State Government made report to Central Government on 5th August 1972

anchor.surface_text: The State Government approved the order of detention on 5th August, 1972 and a report was made by it to the Central Government on the same day.

facts.text: Petitioner was absconding and could not be arrested until 24th October 1972

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the petitioner was absconding and he companyld number, therefore, be arrested pursuant to the order of detention until 24th October, 1972.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 24th October 1972

anchor.surface_text: When the petitioner was arrested on 24th October, 1972, the order of detention was served on him along with the grounds of detention.

facts.text: On arrest, order of detention served along with grounds of detention

anchor.surface_text: When the petitioner was arrested on 24th October, 1972, the order of detention was served on him along with the grounds of detention.

facts.text: State Government placed case before Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: The State Government thereafter placed the, case of the petitioner before the Advisory Board for its opinion and the Advisory Board submitted a report dated 23rd November, 1972

facts.text: Advisory Board submitted report dated 23rd November 1972 stating sufficient cause for detention

anchor.surface_text: the Advisory Board submitted a report dated 23rd November, 1972 stating that in its opinion there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: No representation against order received from petitioner until 27th November 1972

anchor.surface_text: Now, right up to this time numberrepresentation against the order of detention was received from the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government received representation from petitioner on 27th November 1972

anchor.surface_text: It was only on 27th November, 1972 that the State Government received the representation of the petitioner against the order of detention.

facts.text: State Government had not yet confirmed order when representation received

anchor.surface_text: The State Government had number yet companyfirmed the order of detention when the representation was received

facts.text: State Government passed order of confirmation on 29th November 1972 without considering representation

anchor.surface_text: but even so the State Government proceeded to companyfirm the order of detention without companysidering the representation. The order of companyfirmation was passed by the State Government on 29th November, 1972.

facts.text: State Government considered and rejected representation on 2nd December 1972

anchor.surface_text: The State Government thereafter companysidered the representation of the petitioner and rejected the same on 2nd December, 1972.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that confirmation without considering representation violates Art 22(5) and s7 MISA

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, on these facts, companytended that the order companyfirming the detention of the petitioner having been passed by the State Government without companysidering the representation of the petitioner, the detention of the petitioner was unlawful as being in violation of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution and section 7 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

facts.text: Court held detention unlawful due to confirmation without considering representation

anchor.surface_text: This companytention has great force and it must result in the detention of the petitioner being set aside.

facts.text: Court set aside order of detention and declared detention illegal and void

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order of detention and declare the detention of the petitioner to be illegal and void and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- BHAGWATI J.-This petition is directed against the validity of an order of detention dated 26th July, 1972

facts.text: Petitioner urged several grounds but court focused on one

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has urged several grounds before us,- but it is number necessary to refer to them since there is one ground which is, in our opinion, sufficient to dispose of the petition in favour

facts.text: Hira Lal Jain appeared for the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: Hira Lal Jain, for the petitioner. Laila Seth and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent.

facts.text: Laila Seth and G. S. Chatterjee for the respondent

anchor.surface_text: Laila Seth and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- BHAGWATI J.-This petition is directed
Writ Petition No. 164 of 1974. Petition Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

This petition is directed against the validity of an order of detention dated 26th July, 1972 made by the District Magistrate, Midnapur under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

issues.text: Whether the order confirming the detention of the petitioner having been passed by the State Government without considering the representation of the petitioner, the detention of the petitioner was unlawful as being in violation of Art. 22(5) of the Constitution and section 7 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971

anchor.surface_text: the order confirming the detention of the petitioner having been passed by the State Government without considering the representation of the petitioner, the detention of the petitioner was unlawful as being in violation of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution and section 7 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

issues.text: Whether the State Government is bound to consider the detenu's representation as soon as it is received by it before confirming the detention order, pursuant to Article 22(5) of the Constitution, section 7 of MISA and the principles laid down in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: This contention has great force and it must result in the detention of the petitioner being set aside. it is now well settled by a decision of five judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukula v. State of West Bengal 1  that the peremptory language of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution and section 7 of the Act makes it obligatory that the State Government should consider the representation of the detenu as soon as it is received by it.

issues.text: Whether the State Government must consider the representation received after the Advisory Board has submitted its report but before the detention order is confirmed

anchor.surface_text: Here the representation of the petitioner was received by the State Government after the Advisory Board had made its report and there could then be no question of sending the representation to the Advisory Board. But the State Government had not yet confirmed the order of detention and it was, therefore, bound to consider the representation of the petitioner. It is obvious that even where the Advisory Board reports that there is in its opinion sufficient cause for the detention of the detenu, the State Government is not bound to confirm the order of detention.

issues.text: Whether there is any obligation on the State Government to forward a representation received after thirty days from the date of detention to the Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: so long as the representation is received within thirty days from the date of the detentions the State Government would be bound to forward it to the Advisory Board. But a question may arise as to what would be the duty of the State Government where the representation is received after the expiration of thirty days from the date of detention. It was contended on behalf of the State that in such a case there would be noobligation of the State Government to send the representation to the Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: it is now well settled by a decision of five judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukula v. State of West Bengal 1  that the peremptory language of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution and section 7

arguments.claim: The requirement of Art. 22(5) of the Constitution that the authority making the order of detention should afford the detenu the earliest opportunity of making a representation against the order of detention would become illusory if there were no corresponding obligation on the State Government to consider the representation of the detenu as early as possible

anchor.surface_text: The requirement of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution that the authority making the order of detention should afford the detenu the earliest opportunity of making a repre- sentation against the order

arguments.claim: It is not enough for the State Government to forward the representation to the Advisory Board while seeking its opinion as to whether there is sufficient cause for the detention of the detenu. The State Government must itself consider the representation of the detenu and come to its own conclusion whether it is necessary to detain the detenu

anchor.surface_text: It is not enough for the State Government to forward the representation to the Advisory Board while seeking its opinion as to whether there is sufficient cause for the detention of the detenu.

arguments.claim: In such a case [where representation received after expiration of thirty days from the date of detention] there would be no obligation of the State Government to send the representation to the Advisory Board, because the State Government being bound to place the case of the detenu before the Advisory Board within thirty days from the date of detention, if the representation is not received within the period of thirty days, there can be no obligation of the State Government to forward it to the Advisory Board

holdings.text: The detention of the petitioner is unlawful as the order confirming the detention was passed by the State Government without considering the representation of the petitioner, in violation of Article 22(5) of the Constitution and section 7 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971

anchor.surface_text: This contention has great force and it must result in the detention of the petitioner being set aside. it is now well settled by a decision of five judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukula v. State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's contention accepted as having great force; applies peremptory obligation under Art.22(5) and s.7 MISA requiring consideration of representation before confirmation

holdings.text: The peremptory language of Article 22(5) of the Constitution and section 7 of MISA makes it obligatory for the State Government to consider the representation of the detenu as soon as it is received by it

anchor.surface_text: it is now well settled by a decision of five judges of this Court in Jayanarayan Sukula v. State of West Bengal 1  that the peremptory language of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution and section 7

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent of five-judge bench in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal; interprets constitutional and statutory language as imposing immediate obligation

holdings.text: The four principles enunciated in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal regarding consideration of detenu's representation are binding: (1) consider as early as possible; (2) independent of Advisory Board; (3) no delay; (4) decide before referring to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: This Court, speaking through Ray, J., as he then was, in Jayanarayan Sukul v. State of West Bengal,  supra  enunciated the following four principles to be followed in regard to the representation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly restates and applies the four principles laid down by this Court in Jayanarayan Sukul as mandatory procedures

holdings.text: Where representation is received after Advisory Board report but before confirmation of detention order, the State Government is bound to consider it before confirming, as it must apply its mind independently even if Advisory Board finds sufficient cause

anchor.surface_text: Here the representation of the petitioner was received by the State Government after the Advisory Board had made its report and there could then be no question of sending the representation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Jayanarayan principles and s.11 MISA; State Govt not bound by Advisory Board opinion and must consider all materials including representation before confirming

holdings.text: Subsequent consideration and rejection of the representation after passing the confirmation order cannot cure the invalidity of the confirmation order made without considering the representation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to consider at time of confirmation is fatal procedural defect; supported by analogy to B. Sunder Rao v. State of Orissa

holdings.text: The order of detention and detention of the petitioner are illegal and void; the petitioner is to be set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order of detention and declare the detention of the petitioner to be illegal and void and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of violation of mandatory procedural safeguards under Art.22(5), s.7 and s.11 MISA and Jayanarayan principles
